name: Gurdwara Darbar Sahib Kartarpur (Kartarpur Sahib)
category: Gurus (Associated with Guru Nanak Dev Ji, founder of Sikhism)
birthPlace: Kartarpur, Shakargarh Tehsil, Narowal District, Punjab, Pakistan
excerpt: Kartarpur Sahib is one of the holiest sites in Sikhism, marking the place where Guru Nanak Dev Ji, the founder of the faith, spent his final 18 years establishing the first Sikh community, preaching core principles, and attaining enlightenment in 1539 CE. It symbolizes the foundations of Sikh egalitarian ideals and communal living.
designation: Holiest Gurdwara in Sikhism (Second after Gurdwara Janam Asthan in Nankana Sahib)

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Kartarpur Sahib was founded around 1504 CE by Guru Nanak Dev Ji near the Ravi River in present-day Pakistan. After his extensive missionary travels (Udasis) across regions like Haridwar, Mecca, Lanka, Baghdad, Kashmir, and Nepal, Guru Nanak settled here, plowing fields and establishing the first Sikh commune. The site served as a model village emphasizing communal harmony, equality, and spiritual practice. (Source: Wikipedia)

biographySections.label: Contributions/Service
biographySections.value: The site became the cradle of Sikhism, where Guru Nanak assembled followers, instituted the Langar (community kitchen) for free meals regardless of caste or creed, and promoted ethical living. It fostered a self-sustaining community through farming and honest labor, laying the groundwork for Sikh institutions. Today, the gurdwara preserves relics like original copies of the Guru Granth Sahib and serves as a pilgrimage center. (Source: SikhiWiki, Wikipedia)

biographySections.label: Key Reforms
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak introduced reforms against social inequalities, emphasizing gender equality, rejection of caste systems, and interfaith harmony through the principle of Ik Onkar (One God). The site's establishment challenged prevailing religious and social norms by creating an egalitarian society. (citationNeeded for specific reform dates)

biographySections.label: Compositions/Writings
biographySections.value: While not a person, the site is linked to Guru Nanak's compositions in the Guru Granth Sahib, including hymns composed during his time here. Key teachings like the three pillars (Kirat Karo, Naam Japo, Vand Chhako) were formalized at Kartarpur. (Source: Research_For_Personality search results)

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: Guru Nanak resided here until his death (Joti Jot) on September 22, 1539 CE. A legendary dispute arose post-death between Hindus (favoring cremation) and Muslims (favoring burial), resolved by covering his body with flowers that miraculously bloomed, symbolizing unity. His ashes were later moved due to flooding. The gurdwara was built on this sacred spot. (Source: Wikipedia)

spiritualLegacy.description: Kartarpur Sahib embodies the birth of organized Sikhism, representing Guru Nanak's vision of a society based on truth, equality, and devotion. It remains a beacon for Sikhs worldwide, promoting peace and universal brotherhood.
keyContributions: Establishment of Langar system, promoting communal equality.
Codification of core Sikh ethics: honest work, remembrance of God, and sharing.
Foundation for the Guru Granth Sahib's compilation through preserved teachings.

modernRelevance.description: In contemporary times, Kartarpur Sahib symbolizes Sikh resilience and cross-border harmony. The 2019 Kartarpur Corridor allows Indian pilgrims visa-free access, fostering Indo-Pak relations and global Sikh unity.
contemporaryImpact: Annual Gurpurab gatherings draw millions, reinforcing cultural identity.
Serves as a diplomatic bridge, highlighted during Guru Nanak's 550th birth anniversary celebrations.
Inspires modern Sikh activism for social justice and interfaith dialogue.

historicalContext.period: Early Sikhism (15th-16th century CE), during Mughal and Delhi Sultanate influences in Punjab.
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Under varying Muslim rulers; Guru Nanak's teachings challenged rigid theocracies by promoting spiritual equality over ritualism.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Prevalent caste discrimination, gender inequality, and religious divisions; Kartarpur offered a revolutionary egalitarian alternative.
historicalContext.significance: Marked the transition from Guru Nanak's itinerant preaching to institutionalized Sikh community, influencing the formation of the faith amid socio-political turbulence. (Source: Wikipedia History section)
